TITLE.P: Improving Sustainable Tourism in Mauritius Through Greening the Value Chain of Tour Operators

SHORT_DESCR.P: We intend to award a contract to an International Sustainable Destination Expert for the following project Improving Sustainable Tourism in Mauritius Through Greening the Value Chain of Tour Operators (SUS-ISLAND).

SUS-ISLAND is a 48-month Switch Africa Green project. It is jointly implemented by Mauritius Tourism Authority (MTA) and Collaborating Centre on Sustainable Consumption and Production (CSCP), with funding from the European Commission. The overall objective of SUS-ISLAND is to promote sustainable tourism in Mauritius by demonstrating and scaling up a self-sustaining mechanism for improving sustainability impacts along the value chain, and improving awareness and market of sustainable tourism products.

MAIN_SITE.P: Main site or place of performance will be Germany, but work will also be possible from other EU member states.

SHORT_DESCR.P: Guiding sustainable innovation of tour operators and hotels.

SUS-ISLAND is a 48-month Switch Africa Green project. It is jointly implemented by Mauritius Tourism Authority (MTA) and Collaborating Centre on Sustainable Consumption and Production (CSCP), with funding from the European Commission.

Mauritius Tourism Authority (MTA) is a parastatal body operating under the aegis of the Ministry of Tourism (MoT). It aims to promote sustainable development of the tourism industry. MTA and MoT have developed the sustainable tourism standard (MS165) and launched support scheme to a scheme to support Micro, Small & Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) according to the eco-label criteria. In this regard, 10 tourism enterprises (including hotels and tour operators) were selected to pilot the application of the eco-labelling scheme. The results demonstrated that the enterprises require robust business cases in order to actively engage in the eco-labelling scheme. Meanwhile, responsible international wholesalers have been working on boosting their competitiveness by improving their sustainability impacts, including reducing the negative impacts (e.g. GHG emission, resource consumption), and improving the positive impacts (e.g. local community empowerment, quality lifestyle). Based on the foregoing, CSCP had been in discussion with pioneering tourism wholesalers to develop and test reliable mechanisms to raise the added-value of the products through sustainable innovation. The handprint method piloted by the CSCP serves as a promising solution, as it measures and communicates the positive sustainability impacts of products to strengthen innovations that create positive impacts (handprint) and reduce negative impacts (footprint). Against this background, MTA and CSCP in consultation with industry associations and MSMEs representatives have co-designed the SUS-ISLAND project.

The overall objective of SUS-ISLAND is to promote sustainable tourism in Mauritius by demonstrating and scaling up a self-sustaining mechanism for improving sustainability impacts along the value chain, and improving awareness and market of sustainable tourism products. Leveraging the significant role played by TOs as one of the major economic agents of mass tourism, SUS-ISLAND intends to position Mauritius as a sustainability beacon among the Vanilla Islands. Specifically, SUS-ISLAND will support TOs and their suppliers to develop, promote and scale up sustainable tourism innovation, which reduces their respective value chain footprints (negative sustainability impacts, e.g. resource and energy consumption, pollution etc.), improves handprints (positive sustainability impacts, including green jobs generation, local community empowerment, sustainability awareness, quality of life etc.) and improves tourists’ satisfaction. SUS-ISLAND, therefore, contributes to expanding both the supply and demand of sustainable tourism products.
As to specific objectives of SUS-ISLAND see detailed ToR.
In this backdrop, the following intervention from an international sustainable destination expert is of paramount importance for promoting sustainable tourism in Mauritius.
— Guiding pro-handprint innovation of tour operators and hotels.

TECHNICAL_PROFESSIONAL_INFO.P: — Master’s degree or equivalent in development studies, environmental management, tourism, economics, business development, SCP or related fields with minimum 10 years post qualifying experience (5 points);

— Should have experience in sustainable tourism destination development. Recent experience (within the past 2 years) in introducing sustainable destination guidelines, measurement system and policy suggestions will be a distinct advantage (25 points);
— At least 5 years of experience in the discipline of SCP or related disciplines;
— Existing relationship with tour operators working with Mauritius (5 points);
— Prior work experience with tour operators in products development and marketing (25 points);
— Expertise and proven track record of sustainable hotel management, operation, value chain management and marketing (25 points);
— Excellent communications and reporting capabilities (10 points);
— Fluency in English Language and good working knowledge of common ICT tools (5 points).

INFO_ADD.P: 4) Suggested activities of this assignment
Given below are the suggested activities of this assignment to meet the specific objectives:
— Take stock of the existing sustainable tourism eco-labelling scheme and criteria;

— Co-develop and review the Mauritius Pro-Handprint Innovation (MauPHI) Framework, which is to guide the tourism actors (particularly TOs and hotels) to achieve improved sustainable impacts and customer satisfaction in the follow 4 steps.
1) Identify Mauritian Pro-Handprint Innovation (MauPHI) targets;
2) Generate innovation ideas that creates more positive impacts;
3) Implement MauPHI actions;
4) Measure MauPHI impacts.
For more information on the pro-handprint approach refer to http://www.handabdruck.org.
— Draw from the success stories, industrial experience and good practices of sustainable tourism innovation on the development of MauPHI criteria, innovation ideation tool, and MauPHI guidelines;
— Engage and guide one pilot tour operator in developing and implementing MauPHI actions;
— Support scaling up of the MauPHI process with selected TOs through training of the trainers and helpdesk;
— Lead the MauPHI process in 10 selected hotels, and training the local trainers for replication;
— Develop MauPHI communication guidelines;
— Guide the pilot TOs and hotels on marketing MauPHI products;
— Support policy development and improvement;
— Support MauPHI campaign for tourists and travel agencies.
5) Deliverables
Given below are the expected deliverables of this assignment:
— MauPHI Framework co-developed with CSCP (the expert leading the tools development supporting Step 2 and 3);
— MauPHI actions implemented in the pilot TO, including MauPHI product introduced and marketed;
— Training of the trainers on how to coach TOs in implementing MauPHI actions;
— Consolidated toolkits on guiding MauPHI actions in the hotels;
— MauPHI actions implemented in 10 pilot hotels, including MauPHI product introduced and marketed;
— Training of the trainers on how to coach TOs in implementing MauPHI actions;
— Co-delivered seminar for MSMEs on MauPHI productization and communication;
— Reviewed policy research outcome and advice on the policy recommendation;
— Co-delivered MauPHI campaign towards tourists and travel agencies.
6) Travel
It is foreseen that the expert:
— needs to travel to Mauritius for the completion of the tasks (up to 8 trips).
— may need to travel within Europe (2 trips).
8) Information needed with the application
— Technical offer, including.

—— Updated CV giving full qualifications/competencies and relevant past experience in similar projects. Note: It is advisable to prepare a specific CV to suit the requirements mentioned under Section 7 of this TOR by paying special attention to the marking scheme suggested,
—— A methodology on how the applicant will approach and conduct the work.
—— Financial offer.
9) Deadline for application
— Application closes 3 weeks after calling for applications.
